Literature Review: The study of drying drops of colloidal dispersions has been a subject of scientific interest for over a century, captivating researchers with its multifaceted nature and complex physicochemical processes. This field of study encompasses a wide range of phenomena, from colloidal interactions to interfacial dynamics and transport processes, all of which contribute to the intricate patterns observed when these drops evaporate on surfaces.One of the most well-known phenomena associated with drying colloidal drops is the 'coffee ring effect,' first described by Deegan et al. in 1997 [1]. This effect occurs when suspended particles in an evaporating drop are deposited at the periphery, forming a ring-like structure. The mechanism behind this effect involves capillary flow induced by pinned contact lines and differential evaporation rates across the drop surface. Since its discovery, numerous studies have explored the factors influencing the coffee ring effect and ways to control or suppress it for various applications.The evaporation kinetics of sessile drops play a crucial role in determining the final deposition patterns. Hu and Larson [2] developed a theoretical model to describe the evaporation flux distribution along the surface of a sessile drop, which has become a fundamental tool for understanding the drying process. Their work highlighted the importance of the drop geometry, particularly the contact angle, in determining the evaporation rate and internal flows.Internal flows within drying drops have been extensively studied due to their significant impact on particle deposition. Marangoni flows, driven by surface tension gradients, can counteract the outward capillary flow and lead to more uniform deposition patterns. Ristenpart et al. [3] demonstrated that the direction of these flows depends on the relative thermal properties of the substrate and the liquid, providing insights into how to manipulate deposition patterns by choosing appropriate substrate materials.The nature of the dispersed particles themselves greatly influences the drying process and resulting patterns. Yunker et al. [4] showed that the shape of colloidal particles can dramatically affect the coffee ring effect. They found that ellipsoidal particles tend to form more uniform deposits compared to spherical particles due to the formation of loosely packed structures at the air-water interface. This discovery opened up new avenues for controlling deposition patterns by engineering particle shape.In recent years, there has been growing interest in the drying of complex fluids, such as polymer solutions and biological fluids. These systems often exhibit non-Newtonian behavior and can form intricate structures during drying. For instance, Pauchard and Allain [5] observed that drying polymer solution drops can undergo a 'buckling' instability, resulting in complex three-dimensional shapes. Such phenomena highlight the interplay between evaporation-induced concentration changes and the rheological properties of the fluid.The substrate properties also play a crucial role in determining the final deposition patterns. Eral et al. [6] demonstrated that substrate wettability and topography can significantly influence particle deposition. Hydrophobic substrates or those with engineered surface patterns can be used to control drop shape and internal flows, leading to more uniform deposits or specific pattern formations.Environmental conditions, such as temperature and humidity, have been shown to have a substantial impact on the drying process. Doi et al. [7] investigated the effect of ambient humidity on the evaporation rate and internal flows of colloidal drops. They found that higher humidity leads to slower evaporation rates and can suppress Marangoni flows, affecting the final deposition patterns.The study of drying drops has expanded beyond simple sessile drops to include more complex configurations. For example, Sefiane et al. [8] explored the evaporation of drops on micropillared surfaces, revealing intricate dynamics of contact line motion and pattern formation. Similarly, the drying of drops in confined geometries, such as microfluidic channels, has attracted attention due to its relevance in various technological applications.Recent advancements in imaging techniques have greatly enhanced our understanding of the processes occurring within drying drops. Marin et al. [9] used high-speed confocal microscopy to visualize the three-dimensional particle dynamics during evaporation, providing unprecedented insights into the mechanisms of pattern formation. Such techniques have revealed complex phenomena like stratification in multicomponent colloidal mixtures during drying.The field of drying colloidal dispersions continues to evolve, with new applications emerging in areas such as inkjet printing, biosensing, and nanomaterial fabrication. Kuang et al. [10] demonstrated the use of controlled evaporative deposition for creating functional nanostructured surfaces with applications in optoelectronics and energy harvesting. These developments highlight the practical importance of understanding and controlling the drying process of colloidal dispersions.In conclusion, the study of drying drops of colloidal dispersions remains a rich and active area of research, combining fundamental physical principles with practical applications. As our understanding of the underlying mechanisms continues to grow, so too does our ability to control and exploit these phenomena for technological advancements across various fields.
